questions.questionText: What is the standard general lighting load per square foot for dwelling units according to NEC Table 220.12?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 220.12 specifies 3 VA per square foot for general lighting loads in dwelling units. This value is used to calculate the minimum branch circuit load for lighting.
questions.sparkyTip: Remember: 3 VA for dwelling units - think of it as '3 rooms in a home' to help you remember!

questions.questionText: What is the standard small-appliance branch circuit load for a dwelling unit with two 20-ampere circuits?
questions.explanation: NEC 220.52(A) requires a minimum of two 20-ampere small-appliance branch circuits, and 220.52(A)(1) specifies each circuit shall be calculated at 1,500 VA.
questions.sparkyTip: Small appliance circuits = 1,500 VA each. Easy to remember: 15 amps × 100 = 1,500!

questions.questionText: When calculating demand for household clothes dryers, what is the minimum demand load per dryer if the nameplate rating is unknown?
questions.explanation: NEC 220.54 states that the load for household clothes dryers shall be either 5,000 watts (volt-amperes) or the nameplate rating, whichever is larger.
questions.sparkyTip: 5,000 watts minimum for dryers - think of it as 'high five' for your dryer load!

questions.questionText: What is the demand factor for the first 10 kVA of general lighting load in dwelling unit calculations?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 220.42 specifies 100% demand factor for the first 10,000 VA of general lighting load. Only amounts over 10 kVA get the 35% reduction.
questions.sparkyTip: First 10 kVA at 100%, then 35% for the rest. Don't discount the first chunk!

questions.questionText: For dwelling units, what is the demand factor applied to general lighting loads that exceed 10,000 VA?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 220.42 allows a 35% demand factor for lighting loads that exceed 10,000 VA in dwelling units. This recognizes that not all lights are on simultaneously.
questions.sparkyTip: Over 10 kVA? Apply 35%. Think 'after 10, things get lean at 35%!'

questions.questionText: When calculating dwelling unit loads using the optional method (220.82), what percentage is applied to the first 10 kVA of general loads?
questions.explanation: NEC 220.82(B) specifies 100% of the first 10 kVA when using the optional calculation method for dwelling units. Loads over 10 kVA use 40%.
questions.sparkyTip: Optional method: 100% for first 10kVA, then 40% for the rest. Simple two-tier calculation!

questions.questionText: Using the optional calculation method (220.82), what percentage is applied to general loads exceeding 10 kVA?
questions.explanation: NEC 220.82(B) applies 40% to the portion of general loads exceeding 10 kVA. This simplified method often results in smaller service sizes than the standard method.
questions.sparkyTip: 40% after 10 kVA in the optional method - that's why customers love it: smaller service = savings!

questions.questionText: How many VA must be included for each laundry circuit in a dwelling unit load calculation?
questions.explanation: NEC 220.52(B) requires at least one 20-ampere laundry branch circuit, and it shall be calculated at 1,500 VA.
questions.sparkyTip: Laundry circuit = 1,500 VA, just like small appliance circuits. Consistency is key!

questions.questionText: What is the demand factor for four or more household cooking appliances rated over 1¾ kW but not more than 8¾ kW?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 220.55 must be used for household cooking appliances over 1¾ kW. The demand factors vary based on the number of appliances and their wattage.
questions.sparkyTip: Always go to Table 220.55 for cooking appliances - it's your cooking demand cheat sheet!

questions.questionText: Per NEC Table 220.55, what is the maximum demand in kW for a single household range rated not more than 12 kW?
questions.explanation: Table 220.55, Column C shows that one household range rated not more than 12 kW has a maximum demand of 8 kW. This significant reduction recognizes that all elements rarely operate simultaneously at full power.
questions.sparkyTip: One range up to 12 kW = 8 kW demand. The NEC knows your stove isn't cooking everything at once!

questions.questionText: What demand factor can be applied to four or more fastened-in-place appliances in a dwelling unit?
questions.explanation: NEC 220.53 allows a 75% demand factor for four or more fastened-in-place appliances (other than cooking equipment, dryers, and heating/AC). This includes appliances like water heaters, dishwashers, and disposals.
questions.sparkyTip: Four or more fixed appliances? Take 75%. Not everything runs at once!

questions.questionText: When calculating branch circuit loads, what is the continuous load multiplier?
questions.explanation: NEC 210.20(A) requires that branch circuits supplying continuous loads shall have an ampacity of at least 125% of the continuous load (plus 100% of non-continuous loads).
questions.sparkyTip: Continuous loads = 125%. Add that extra 25% for loads running 3+ hours!

questions.questionText: For multifamily dwellings, what is the demand factor for clothes dryers when there are 12 dryers?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 220.54 shows that for 12 dryers, the demand factor is 47%. The demand factor decreases as the number of dryers increases because they won't all operate simultaneously.
questions.sparkyTip: More dryers = lower demand factor. Check Table 220.54 for the exact percentages!

questions.questionText: The lighting load for a 2,000 square foot dwelling unit using standard calculation method is:
questions.explanation: 2,000 sq ft × 3 VA/sq ft = 6,000 VA. NEC Table 220.12 specifies 3 VA per square foot for dwelling unit general lighting load calculations.
questions.sparkyTip: Square footage × 3 = lighting VA. Quick math for every dwelling unit!

questions.questionText: When using the standard calculation for a dwelling with electric heating at 10 kW and air conditioning at 5 kW, what load is used?
questions.explanation: NEC 220.60 allows omitting the smaller of two loads if they cannot operate simultaneously. Since heating and cooling don't run at the same time, use only the larger load (10 kW).
questions.sparkyTip: Heating vs. cooling - use the bigger one! They don't run together, so why calculate both?

questions.questionText: What is the minimum number of small-appliance branch circuits required for a dwelling unit kitchen and dining area?
questions.explanation: NEC 210.11(C)(1) requires a minimum of two 20-ampere small-appliance branch circuits to supply receptacle outlets in the kitchen, pantry, breakfast room, and dining room.
questions.sparkyTip: Two small appliance circuits minimum - one for each side of the kitchen counter!

questions.questionText: For a commercial building, what is the lighting load per square foot for an office building per NEC Table 220.12?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 220.12 specifies 3½ VA per square foot for office buildings. Different occupancy types have different lighting load requirements.
questions.sparkyTip: Offices need 3½ VA/sq ft - a little more than dwellings due to task lighting needs!

questions.questionText: What is the minimum size copper grounding electrode conductor for a 200-ampere service?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 250.66 specifies a minimum #4 AWG copper grounding electrode conductor for service entrance conductors up to 2/0 AWG copper or 4/0 AWG aluminum.
questions.sparkyTip: 200-amp service = #4 copper GEC. Match the service size to Table 250.66!

questions.questionText: What is the minimum burial depth for a ground rod?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.53(G) requires rod electrodes to be installed so that at least 8 feet (2.44 m) of length is in contact with the soil.
questions.sparkyTip: Ground rods need 8 feet in the earth - think 'great 8' for ground rods!

questions.questionText: When a single ground rod has a resistance greater than 25 ohms, what is required?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.53(A)(2) requires that if a single rod electrode has a resistance to earth greater than 25 ohms, it shall be augmented by one additional electrode.
questions.sparkyTip: Over 25 ohms? Add another rod! Two rods are the solution to high resistance.

questions.questionText: What is the minimum spacing between two ground rods?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.53(A)(3) requires that when more than one rod electrode is used, they shall be spaced not less than 6 feet apart.
questions.sparkyTip: 6 feet between rods minimum - give them room to do their job effectively!

questions.questionText: The grounding electrode conductor connects the grounding electrode to the:
questions.explanation: The grounding electrode conductor connects the grounding electrode system to the grounded service conductor (neutral) at the service equipment, as specified in NEC 250.24(A).
questions.sparkyTip: GEC goes from ground rod to neutral bar at service - that's where earth meets the system!

questions.questionText: What is the maximum length of a copper bonding jumper for a 2-inch trade size rigid metal conduit at a service?
questions.explanation: For service equipment, the bonding jumper size is determined by NEC Table 250.102(C)(1), which is based on the size of the largest service entrance conductor.
questions.sparkyTip: Service bonding = Table 250.102(C). Different from equipment grounding conductor sizing!

questions.questionText: What is the minimum size equipment grounding conductor for a 60-ampere circuit?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 250.122 specifies a minimum #10 AWG copper equipment grounding conductor for overcurrent devices rated 60 amperes.
questions.sparkyTip: Table 250.122 is your EGC sizing guide - match the breaker size to find your wire!

questions.questionText: A metal underground water pipe must be supplemented by an additional electrode if it is the sole grounding electrode and extends less than how many feet?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.52(A)(1) requires a metal underground water pipe to be in direct contact with the earth for 10 feet or more to qualify as a grounding electrode without supplementation.
questions.sparkyTip: Water pipe electrode needs 10 feet in earth - if less, it needs a buddy electrode!

questions.questionText: The main bonding jumper at service equipment connects the neutral bus to the:
questions.explanation: NEC 250.28 requires the main bonding jumper to connect the grounded conductor (neutral) to the equipment grounding conductor and the equipment enclosure at the service.
questions.sparkyTip: Main bonding jumper bridges neutral to ground at service - the only place they should meet!

questions.questionText: At what point must the grounded conductor (neutral) and equipment grounding conductor be bonded together?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.24(A)(5) and 250.142(B) prohibit connecting the grounded conductor to equipment grounding conductors or equipment on the load side of the service disconnecting means, except in specific circumstances.
questions.sparkyTip: Neutral-ground bond ONLY at service! In subpanels, keep them separate.

questions.questionText: What is the minimum size copper bonding conductor for a gas piping system where the upstream gas pipe bonding point is supplied by a 100A circuit?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.104(B) requires bonding of metal gas piping. The bonding conductor size is based on Table 250.122 using the rating of the circuit that could energize the piping. For 100A, that's #6 AWG copper.
questions.sparkyTip: Gas pipe bonding uses Table 250.122 - size it like an equipment grounding conductor!

questions.questionText: What is the diameter of a standard ground rod?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.52(A)(5) requires rod electrodes to have a minimum diameter of ⅝ inch (15.87 mm) for standard ground rods. Stainless steel or nonferrous rods can be ½ inch.
questions.sparkyTip: Standard ground rod = ⅝ inch diameter. It's the industry standard!

questions.questionText: What color is required for insulated equipment grounding conductors?
options: Green or green with yellow stripes
questions.explanation: NEC 250.119 requires equipment grounding conductors to be identified by a continuous green color or green with one or more yellow stripes.
questions.sparkyTip: Green for ground - it's easy to remember: G for Green, G for Ground!

questions.questionText: For a separately derived system (transformer), the grounding electrode conductor size is based on:
options: Table 250.66 based on derived phase conductors
questions.explanation: NEC 250.30(A)(6) requires the grounding electrode conductor for separately derived systems to be sized per Table 250.66, based on the derived phase conductors.
questions.sparkyTip: Separately derived systems use Table 250.66 too - based on secondary conductor size!

questions.questionText: Bonding of metal water piping in a building must be done with a conductor not smaller than:
questions.explanation: NEC 250.104(A)(1) requires the bonding conductor for interior metal water piping to be sized per Table 250.66, based on the size of the service entrance conductors.
questions.sparkyTip: Water pipe bonding = Table 250.66. Size it like your GEC!

questions.questionText: The intersystem bonding termination device must be capable of terminating how many conductors?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.94 requires an intersystem bonding termination that provides connection capacity for at least 3 intersystem bonding conductors (for cable, telephone, etc.).
questions.sparkyTip: Intersystem bonding = 3 terminations minimum. One for each utility that might need it!

questions.questionText: Where is the system grounding connection typically made for a grounded electrical system?
questions.explanation: NEC 250.24(A)(1) requires the grounding electrode conductor connection to be made at any accessible point from the load end of the service drop to the service disconnecting means.
questions.sparkyTip: System ground connects at the service - that's home base for your grounding!

questions.questionText: What is the maximum number of service disconnects allowed for a single service?
questions.explanation: NEC 230.71(A) limits the number of service disconnecting means to a maximum of 6 switches or circuit breakers, mounted in a single enclosure or grouped together.
questions.sparkyTip: Six throws max to turn off the service - remember the 'rule of six!'

questions.questionText: What is the minimum service size required for a single-family dwelling?
questions.explanation: NEC 230.79(C) requires a minimum 100-ampere, 3-wire service for a single-family dwelling with an initial installation of more than two 2-wire branch circuits.
questions.sparkyTip: 100 amps minimum for homes - the modern standard for residential service!

questions.questionText: What is the minimum height for a service drop over a residential driveway?
questions.explanation: NEC 230.24(B)(1) requires service drop conductors to have a minimum vertical clearance of 12 feet over residential driveways and commercial areas not subject to truck traffic.
questions.sparkyTip: 12 feet over driveways - enough clearance for most vehicles to pass safely!

questions.questionText: What is the minimum clearance from final grade for service entrance conductors on a building?
questions.explanation: NEC 230.24(B)(1) requires a minimum clearance of 10 feet from final grade for service drop conductors installed over areas accessible to pedestrians only.
questions.sparkyTip: 10 feet above walking areas - high enough to stay safe from contact!

questions.questionText: What is the minimum clearance required for service drop conductors over a public street?
questions.explanation: NEC 230.24(B)(4) requires a minimum clearance of 18 feet for service drop conductors over public streets, alleys, roads, and parking areas subject to truck traffic.
questions.sparkyTip: 18 feet over streets - tall trucks need tall clearances!

questions.questionText: Service entrance conductors must be sized to carry at least what percentage of the calculated load?
questions.explanation: NEC 230.42(A)(1) requires service entrance conductors to have an ampacity not less than 100% of the maximum load to be served after applying demand factors.
questions.sparkyTip: Service conductors at 100% of calculated load - after demand factors are applied!

questions.questionText: Service lateral conductors installed underground must have a minimum burial depth of:
questions.explanation: NEC 300.5 provides the burial depth requirements for underground conductors, which varies based on the type of wiring method and location. Service laterals follow these same requirements.
questions.sparkyTip: Underground burial = Table 300.5. The depth depends on what you're burying and where!

questions.questionText: The service point is defined as the point of connection between:
options: The utility facilities and premises wiring
questions.explanation: NEC Article 100 defines the service point as the point of connection between the facilities of the serving utility and the premises wiring. The location is determined by the utility.
questions.sparkyTip: Service point = where utility responsibility ends and yours begins!

questions.questionText: What is required when more than one building is supplied from a single service?
options: A disconnecting means at each building
questions.explanation: NEC 225.32 requires a disconnecting means to be installed at each building or structure supplied by a feeder. This allows the power to be shut off locally for safety.
questions.sparkyTip: One disconnect per building - safety requires local shutoff capability!

questions.questionText: Where must the service disconnecting means be located?
options: At a readily accessible location nearest the point of entrance
questions.explanation: NEC 230.70(A)(1) requires the service disconnecting means to be installed at a readily accessible location either outside the building or inside nearest the point of entrance.
questions.sparkyTip: Service disconnect near the entry point - firefighters need quick access!

questions.questionText: For a 400-ampere service using parallel 200A conductors, what is the maximum overcurrent protection?
questions.explanation: When conductors are installed in parallel, the overcurrent protection is sized based on the total ampacity of the parallel conductors. Two 200A sets can be protected at 400A.
questions.sparkyTip: Parallel conductors = combined ampacity for overcurrent protection!

questions.questionText: Service entrance cables must be supported within how many inches of the service head?
questions.explanation: NEC 230.54(C) requires service entrance cables to be supported within 12 inches of the service head (weatherhead) and at intervals not exceeding 30 inches.
questions.sparkyTip: 12 inches from weatherhead - keep that cable secure at the top!

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of a drip loop on service entrance conductors?
options: To prevent water from entering the raceway
questions.explanation: NEC 230.54(F) requires service entrance conductors to have a drip loop to prevent water from entering the service raceway or equipment. Water runs down and drips off the loop.
questions.sparkyTip: Drip loops keep water out - always form that loop below the weatherhead!

questions.questionText: What is the minimum working clearance in front of a 480V service rated at 200 amperes?
questions.explanation: NEC Table 110.26(A)(1) requires minimum working space based on voltage and conditions. For 480V with exposed live parts on one side only (Condition 1), the minimum is 3½ feet.
questions.sparkyTip: 480V = 3½ feet minimum clearance. Higher voltage needs more room to work safely!

questions.questionText: Emergency disconnects for one- and two-family dwelling units must be located:
options: At or near the service equipment outdoors
questions.explanation: NEC 230.85 (added in 2020) requires an emergency disconnect for one- and two-family dwellings to be installed outdoors at a readily accessible location.
questions.sparkyTip: Emergency disconnect outside - first responders can cut power without entering!

questions.questionText: What is the maximum length of service entrance conductors inside a building without additional protection?
questions.explanation: NEC 230.70(A)(1) requires service conductors inside a building to be as short as practical, as they are not protected by overcurrent devices until they reach the service disconnect.
questions.sparkyTip: Service conductors inside = keep them short! No OCPD protection until the main breaker.
